variableclasses.name: Daily historical weather
variableclasses.comments: Days with missing rainfall data were assumed to have no rainfall, and days with missing temperature or humidity data were not included when computing average temperature or humidity for the fortnight or month containing them.

variables.name: temperature
variables.measurement_location: closest weather station with nearly complete data
variables.measurement_source: Global Surface Summary of the Day (GSOD)

variables.name: precipitation
variables.measurement_location: closest weather station with nearly complete data
variables.measurement_source: Global Surface Summary of the Day (GSOD)

variables.name: dew point
variables.measurement_location: closest weather station with nearly complete data
variables.measurement_source: Global Surface Summary of the Day (GSOD)

variables.name: relative humidity
variables.description: Relative humidity was computed using the following empirical relationship, originally defined by Bosen in 1958. T is temperature in Celsius, DP is dewpoint in Celsius, and RH is relative humidity in percentage

variables.name: Air pressure
variables.description: P is air pressure in kPa

variables.name: saturation vapor pressure
variables.description: E_s is saturation vapor pressure in kPA

variables.name: vapor pressure
variables.description: E is the vapor pressure in kPa

variables.name: specific humidity
variables.description: SH is the specific humidity in g/kg

variableclasses.name: seasons
variableclasses.comments: We identified three data-driven seasons for each GEMS site using rainfall, temperature, and humidity data

variables.name: season
variables.description: We identified three data-driven seasons for each GEMS site using rainfall, temperature, and humidity data. Fig 1(C) illustrates the clustering of monthly weather data, collected from the closest weather station in Bangladesh during 2008 to 2011, projected on to the first two principal components. The color of each month indicates the cluster (season) to which the month belongs.  Fig (1D) illustrates how the clustering is reflected temporally during the study time period. This methodology allows for seasons to vary in duration and initiation time and is based on site-specific weather data from the duration of study enrollment (S2 Fig).
variables.calculation: We attached labels to these data-driven seasons to aid in interpretability. The labeling procedure consists of two components: the characteristics arising from clustering the weather data and region-specific characteristics. For example, periods encompassing the times of year with the most rainfall were labeled “Monsoon” in regions that experience monsoons and “Rainy” elsewhere. The hottest periods of the year were labeled “Summer” and the coldest peri- ods “Winter” when those terms are used in the region; otherwise, the labels “Hot” and “Cool” were assigned. season labels are internally consistent within a site (e.g., “Summer” is always hotter than “Winter” at a site), but not across sites (“Summer” at one site might be cooler than “Summer” at another)

variables.name: average weather conditions
variables.description: S2 Table summarizes average weather conditions for each season at each site. We found that the weather conditions at each site seemed to fall into a few distinct classes, such as “warm, humid, and rainy”, “hot and dry”, and “cool and rainy”, and these classes broadly agree with informally identified site-specific seasons, such as “summer” and “winter”.
